    <dl>
           <dt>&#x0101; 1</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;</em> the second vowel of the alphabet corresponding to the <em>a</em> in far</dd>

           <dt>&#x0101; 2</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;</em> ind. a particle of reminiscence <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-1, 14 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also of compassion or pain [more correctly written 1. <em>&#x0101;s</em>, q.v.], and of assent <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> [This particle remains unaltered in orthography even before vowels (which causes it to be sometimes confounded with 1. <em>&#x0101;s</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-1, 14.]</dd>

           <dt>&#x0101; 3</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;</em> <em>&#x0101;s</em> m. N. of &#x015a;iva <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; grandfather <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;s</em>), f. N. of Lakshm&#x012b; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

   <dt>&#x0101; 4</dt>
   <dd><em>&#x0101;&#x0341;</em> (as a prefix to verbs, especially of motion, and their derivatives) near, near to, towards (See <em>&#x0101;-&#x221a;kram</em> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; in the Veda, of course, the prefix is separable from the verb </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; in a few cases <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 10, 11 and v, 64, 5, a verb in the imperative is to be supplied </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; with roots like <em>gam</em>, <em>y&#x0101;</em>, and <em>i</em>, 'to go', and 1. <em>d&#x0101;</em>, 'to give', it reverses the action </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; e.g. <em>&#x0101;-gacchati</em>, 'he comes,'<em>&#x0101;-datte</em>, 'he takes'). </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (As a prep. with a preceding acc.) near to, towards, to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (with a preceding noun in the acc., as <em>j&#x00f3;&#x1e63;am</em> or <em>v&#x00e1;ram</em>) for <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (with a following acc.) up to .. exclusively <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (with a preceding abl.) from <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; out of, from among (e.g. <em>bah&#x00fa;bhya &#x0101;&#x0341;</em>, 'from among many') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; towards (only in <em>asm&#x00e1;d &#x0101;&#x0341;</em>, 'towards us') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (with a following abl., <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 2-1, 13 &amp; 3, 10) up to, to, as far as <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; from <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 30, 21 </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (with a preceding loc.) in, at, on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> (As an adv. after words expressing a number or degree) fully, really, indeed (e.g. <em>tr&#x00ed;r &#x0101;&#x0341; div&#x00e1;s</em>, 'quite or fully three times a day        ' </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>mahim&#x0101;&#x0341; v&#x0101;m</em> <em>&#x00ed;ndr&#x00e2;gn&#x012b; p&#x00e1;ni&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;ha</em> <em>&#x0101;&#x0341;</em>, 'your greatness, O Indra and Agni, is most praiseworthy indeed', &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (after a subst. or adj.) 'as, like', (or it simply strengthens the sense of the preceding word) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a>, (after a verb) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> v, 7, 7 and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#KenaUp">KenaUp.</a> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p126-2"></a>[Page 126, Column 2]</font> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (as a conjunctive particle) moreover, further, and (it is placed either between the two words connected [rarely after the second <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 16, 11, or after both <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 92, 8] or, if there are more, after the last [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> iv, 57, 1 and x, 75, 5] </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; also <em>&#x00e2;ta&#x015b; ca</em> s.v.) In classical Sansk&#x1e5b;it it may denote the limit 'to', 'until', 'as far as', 'from', either not including the object named or including it (sometimes with acc. or abl. or forming an adv.), e.g. <em>&#x0101;-mara&#x1e47;am</em> or <em>&#x0101;-maran&#x0101;t</em>, 'till death' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> (cf. <em>&#x0101;-mara&#x1e47;&#x00e2;nta</em> &amp;c.) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x0101;-gop&#x0101;l&#x0101; dvij&#x0101;taya&#x1e25;</em>, 'the twice-born including the cowherds' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> ii, 531 </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x0101;-samudram</em> or <em>&#x0101;-samudr&#x0101;t</em>, 'as far as the ocean' or 'from the ocean' (but not including it) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x0101;-kum&#x0101;ram</em>, 'from a child' or 'from childhood' or 'to a child' (cf. Lat. <em>a puero</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iii, 1403 </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x0101;-kum&#x0101;ram</em> <em>ya&#x015b;a&#x1e25; p&#x0101;&#x1e47;ine&#x1e25;</em>, 'the fame of P&#x0101;&#x1e47;ini extends even to children' </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x0101;j&#x0101;nu-b&#x0101;hu</em> mfn. 'one whose arms reach down to the knees' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> i, 1, 12 </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; ( also <em>&#x0101;kar&#x1e47;a-</em> and <em>&#x0101;janma-</em>) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (cf. <em>&#x0101;-jaras&#x00e1;m</em>, <em>&#x0101;-vyu&#x1e63;&#x00e1;m</em>, <em>&#x0101;-saptama</em>, <em>&#x00f4;ts&#x016b;y&#x00e1;m</em>.) Prefixed to adj. [rarely to subst </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>&#x0101;-kopa</em>] it implies diminution <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 2-2, 18 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Comm">Comm.</a> 'a little', e.g. <em>&#x0101;-pi&#x00f1;jara</em> mfn. a little red, reddish <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> xvi, 51 </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; ( also <em>&#x0101;-pakva</em>, <em>&#x00f4;&#x1e63;&#x1e47;a</em>, &amp;c.) Some commentaries (e.g. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Comm">Comm.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> iii, 8) occasionally give to <em>&#x0101;</em> in this application the meaning <em>samant&#x0101;t</em>, 'all through, completely', as <em>&#x0101;-n&#x012b;la</em>, 'blue all round.'</dd>

   <dt>&#x0101;kan </dt>

   <dt>&#x0101;kamp </dt>
   <dd><em>&#x0101;-&#x221a;kamp</em> &#x0100;. (perf. <em>-cakampe</em>) to tremble (as the earth) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;d">K&#x0101;d.</a>: Caus.            <dt>&#x226b; &#x0101;kampa </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; reckoning <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; tied, fastened <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;i&#x015b;">&#x015a;i&#x015b;.</a> i, 6 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (= <em>mud</em>) joy <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

           <dt>&#x0101;ka&#x015b;&#x0101;peya </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;ka&#x015b;&#x0101;peya</em> m. a descendant of Aka&#x015b;&#x0101;pa, (g. <em>&#x015b;ubhr&#x00e2;di</em>, q.v.)</dd>

           <dt>&#x0101;ka&#x1e63;a </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;-ka&#x1e63;a</em> m. (&#x221a;<em>ka&#x1e63;</em>, 'to rub'), a touchstone <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

'knowing or teaching the <em>&#x0101;c&#x0101;ra</em> or rules', a spiritual guide or teacher (especially one who invests the student with the sacrificial thread, and instructs him in the Vedas, in the law of sacrifice and religious mysteries [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> ii, 140 ; 171]) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a N. of Dro&#x1e47;a (the teacher of the P&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;avas) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhag">Bhag.</a> i, 2 </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. a spiritual preceptress <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 4-1, 49 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Siddh">Siddh.</a> [The title <em>&#x0101;c&#x0101;rya</em> affixed to names of learned men is rather like our 'Dr.' </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; e.g. <em>r&#x0101;ghav&#x00e2;c&#x0101;rya</em>, &amp;c.]</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x0101;c&#x0101;ryakara&#x1e47;a </dt>

(abl. of 4. <em>a</em>) afterwards, then (often used in a concluding paragraph antithetically to <em>y&#x00e1;d</em>, <em>yad&#x0101;</em>, <em>y&#x00e1;di</em>. and sometimes strengthened by the particles <em>&#x00e1;ha</em>, <em>&#x00ed;d</em>, <em>&#x012b;m</em>, <em>u</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; then, further, also, and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> It is sometimes used after an interrogative pronoun (like <em>u</em>, <em>n&#x00fa;</em>, <em>a&#x1e45;g&#x00e1;</em>) to give emphasis to the pronoun <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a></dd>

           <dd><em>&#x0101;ttha</em> 2. sg. pf. of the defect. &#x221a;1. <em>ah</em>, q.v</dd>

           <dt>&#x0101;tman </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;tm&#x00e1;n</em> <em>&#x0101;</em> m. (variously derived fr. <em>an</em>, to breathe </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>at</em>, to move </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>v&#x0101;</em>, to blow </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>tm&#x00e1;n</em>) the breath <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the soul, principle of life and sensation <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the individual soul, self, abstract individual [e.g. <em>&#x0101;tm&#x00e1;n</em>] (Ved. loc.) <em>dhatte</em>, or <em>karoti</em>, 'he places in himself', makes his own <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> v <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x0101;tman&#x0101; akarot</em>, 'he did it himself' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;d">K&#x0101;d.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x0101;tman&#x0101; vi-&#x221a;yuj</em>, 'to lose one's life' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> vii, 46 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x0101;tman</em> in the sg. is used as reflexive pronoun for all three persons and all three genders, e.g. <em>&#x0101;tm&#x0101;na&#x1e43; s&#x0101; hanti</em>, 'she strikes herself' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>putram &#x0101;tmana&#x1e25; sp&#x1e5b;&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;v&#x0101; nipetatu&#x1e25;</em>, 'they two having touched their son fell down' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> ii, 64, 28 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; [see also below s.v. <em>&#x0101;tman&#x0101;</em>] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; essence, nature, character, peculiarity (often ifc., e.g. <em>karm&#x00e2;tman</em>, &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 97, 11, &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the person or whole body considered as one and opposed to the separate members of the body <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the body <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> i, 14 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;matUp">R&#x0101;matUp.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (ifc.) 'the understanding, intellect, mind', <em>na&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;&#x00e2;tman</em>, <em>mand&#x00e2;&#x25cb;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the highest personal principle of life, Brahma (cf. <em>param&#x00e2;tman</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> x, 8, 44 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> xxxii, 11 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> xiv, &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; effort <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

   <dt>&#x226b; &#x0101;ditya </dt>
   <dd><em>&#x0101;dity&#x00e1;</em> (cf. P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 4-1, 85), mfn. belonging to or coming from Aditi <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> ii, 2, 6, 1 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c. <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p137-2"></a>[Page 137, Column 2]</font> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; m. 'son of Aditi' </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;s</em>), m. pl, N. of seven deities of the heavenly sphere <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ix, 114, 3, &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> iii, 1, 3, 3 (the chief is Varu&#x1e47;a, to whom the N. &#x0100;ditya is especially applicable </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; the succeeding five are Mitra, Aryaman, Bhaga, Daksha, A&#x1e43;&#x015b;a </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; that of the seventh is probably S&#x016b;rya or Savit&#x1e5b;i </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; as a class of deities they are distinct from the <em>vi&#x015b;ve dev&#x0101;&#x1e25;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ChUp">ChUp.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; sometimes their number is supposed to be eight <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;y">S&#x0101;y.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; and in the period of the Br&#x0101;hma&#x1e47;as twelve, as representing the sun in the twelve months of the year <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> iv, 5, 7, 2, &amp;c.) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; N. of a god in general, especially of S&#x016b;rya (the sun) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;i&#x015b;">&#x015a;i&#x015b;.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; N. of Vish&#x1e47;u in his V&#x0101;mana or dwarf <em>avat&#x0101;ra</em> (as son of Ka&#x015b;yapa and Aditi) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ChUp">ChUp.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; the plant Calotropis Gigantea <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (<em>au</em>), m. du., N. of a constellation, the seventh lunar mansion <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. (?) the sun <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> iv, 21 </dd>

   <dd><em>&#x0101;-&#x221a;di&#x015b;</em> P. <em>-did&#x00e9;&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;i</em> [Subj. 3. sg. <em>-dide&#x015b;ati</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> vi, 6, 2, &amp;c.], <em>-di&#x015b;&#x00e1;ti</em> [3. pl. <em>-di&#x015b;anti</em> Impv. 2. sg. <em>-di&#x015b;a</em> impf. 1. sg. <em>&#x00e2;di&#x015b;am</em>, &amp;c.], rarely <em>-di&#x015b;ate</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> viii, 24, 51], inf. <em>-d&#x00ed;&#x015b;e</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ix, 21, 5] and <em>-de&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;um</em> (aor. 3. sg. <em>&#x00e2;dik&#x1e63;at</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;">Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.</a> iii, 3, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 3-1, 45], fut. 1. pl. <em>-dek&#x1e63;y&#x0101;ma&#x1e25;</em>, perf. <em>-dide&#x015b;a</em>) to aim at, have in view </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to threaten <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ix, 21, 5, &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p137-3"></a>[Page 137, Column 3]</font> </dd>

(perf. 3. pl. <em>&#x0101;pir&#x00e9;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ix, 108, 4, p. pf. <em>&#x0101;p&#x0101;n&#x00e1;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ii, 34, 7, but also pres. p. <em>&#x0101;&#x0341;pn&#x0101;na</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 114, 7) to reach, overtake, meet with, fall upon <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to obtain, gain, take possession of <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to undergo, suffer <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to fall, come to any one </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to enter, pervade, occupy </dd>

   <dd>&#x2022; to arrive at one's aim or end, become filled <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> &amp;c.: Caus. P. <em>&#x0101;payati</em>, to cause to reach or obtain or gain <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ChUp">ChUp.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to cause any one to suffer </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to hit <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a>: Desid.    <dd>&#x2022; [probably connected with 1. <em>ap</em> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>apna</em> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; Gk. ?, ? ; Lat. <em>apiscor</em>, <em>aptus</em>, <em>ops</em> ; Old [142, 1] Germ. <em>uoban</em> ; Mod. Germ. <em>&#x016b;0ben</em>.] <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p142-2"></a>[Page 142, Column 2]</font>

           <dt>&#x0101;pr&#x012b; 1</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;-&#x221a;pr&#x012b;</em> P. (<em>-pr&#x012b;&#x1e47;&#x0101;ti</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> ii, 4 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. Subj. 2. sg. <em>-pipr&#x00e1;yas</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ii, 6, 8) to satisfy, conciliate, propitiate, please <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to address or invoke with the &#x0100;pr&#x012b; ( below) verses <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a>: &#x0100;. (impf. <em>&#x00e2;pr&#x012b;&#x1e47;&#x012b;ta</em>) to amuse one's self, be delighted or pleased <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L&#x0101;&#x1e6d;y">L&#x0101;&#x1e6d;y.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x0101;pra 2</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;pra</em> mfn. belonging to or being an &#x0100;pr&#x012b; ( below) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RAnukr">RAnukr.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x0101;pr&#x012b; 2</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;-pr&#x012b;&#x0341;</em> f. gaining one's favour, conciliation, propitiation </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>-pr&#x00ed;yas</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> xi, 7, 19] and <em>-pryas</em> <em>&#x1e47;&#x0101;r&#x0101;y.</em>), f. pl., N. of particular invocations spoken previous to the offering of oblations (according to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r">&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r.</a> iii, 2, 5 seqq. they are different in different schools </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; e.g. <em>s&#x00e1;middho agn&#x00ed;r</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> v, 28, 1, in the school of &#x015a;unaka </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ju&#x1e63;&#x00e1;sva na&#x1e25;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> vii, 2, 1, in that of Vasish&#x1e6d;ha </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>s&#x00e1;middho ady&#x00e1;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> x, 110, 1, in that of others </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N&#x0101;r&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a on this passage gives ten hymns belonging to different schools </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x0101;y">S&#x0101;y.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 13 [<em>s&#x00fa;samiddho na &#x0101;&#x0341; vaha</em>, the &#x0100;pr&#x012b;-hymn of the school of Ka&#x1e47;va], who enumerates twelve &#x0100;pr&#x012b;s and explains that twelve deities are propitiated </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; those deities are personified objects belonging to the fire-sacrifice, viz. the fuel, the sacred grass, the enclosure, &amp;c., all regarded as different forms of Agni </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; hence the objects are also called &#x0100;pr&#x012b;s, or, according to others, the objects are the real &#x0100;pr&#x012b;s, whence the hymns received their names) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r">&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r.</a> &amp;c</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (a vocative following this particle is anud&#x0101;tta <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 8-1, 55.)</dd>

           <dd><em>&#x0101;m&#x00e1;</em> mf(<em>&#x0101;</em>)n. raw, uncooked (opposed to <em>pakva</em>, q.v.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dt>&#x0101;yam </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;-&#x221a;yam</em> P. <em>-yacchati</em> and (Ved.) <em>-yamati</em>, to stretch, lengthen out, extend         <br>          <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L&#x0101;&#x1e6d;y">L&#x0101;&#x1e6d;y.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to stretch (a bow) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to put on (an arrow &amp;c.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to draw near, bring hither </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to fetch, procure <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>

   <dt>&#x22d9; &#x0101;yurveda </dt>
   <dd><em>&#x25cb;veda</em> m. the science of health or medicine (it is classed among sacred sciences, and considered as a supplement of the Atharva-veda </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; it contains eight departments: 1. &#x015a;alya or (removal of) any substance which has entered the body (as extraction of darts, of splinters, &amp;c.) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; 2. &#x015a;&#x0101;l&#x0101;kya or cure of diseases of the eye or ear &amp;c. by &#x015a;al&#x0101;k&#x0101;s or sharp instruments </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; 3. K&#x0101;ya-cikits&#x0101; or cure of diseases affecting the whole body </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; 4. Bh&#x016b;tavidy&#x0101; or treatment of mental diseases supposed to be produced by demoniacal influence </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; 5. Kaum&#x0101;ra-bh&#x1e5b;itya or treatment of children <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p149-1"></a>[Page 149, Column 1]</font> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; 6. Agada-tantra or doctrine of antidotes </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; 7. R&#x0101;s&#x0101;yana-tantra or doctrine of elixirs </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; 8. V&#x0101;j&#x012b;kara&#x1e47;a-tantra or doctrine of aphrodisiacs <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> &amp;c.) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; <em>-dri&#x015b;</em> m. a physician </dd>

   <dd>&#x2022; <em>-ras&#x00e2;yana</em> n. <em>-sarvasva</em> n. <em>-saukhya</em> n. N. of wks</dd>

   <dd><em>&#x0101;-roha</em> m. one who mounts or ascends, a rider (on a horse &amp;c.), one who is seated in a carriage <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>

   <dd>&#x2022; one who is faithful to the religion of his country </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; N. of the race which immigrated from Central Asia into &#x0100;ry&#x0101;varta (opposed to <em>an-&#x0101;rya</em>, <em>dasyu</em>, <em>d&#x0101;sa</em>) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; in later times N. of the first three castes (opposed to <em>&#x015b;&#x016b;dra</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a man highly esteemed, a respectable, honourable man <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a master, an owner <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a friend <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a Vai&#x015b;ya <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; Buddha </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (with Buddhists [P&#x0101;li <em>ayyo</em>, or <em>ariyo</em>]) a man who has thought on the four chief truths of Buddhism ( next col.) and lives accordingly, a Buddhist priest </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a son of Manu S&#x0101;var&#x1e47;a <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (mf(<em>&#x0101;</em> and <em>&#x0101;&#x0341;r&#x012b;</em>)n.) &#x0100;ryan, favourable to the &#x0100;ryan people <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; behaving like an &#x0100;ryan, worthy of one, honourable, respectable, noble <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; of a good family </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; excellent </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; wise </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; suitable </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. a name of P&#x0101;rvat&#x012b; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a kind of metre of two lines (each line consisting of seven and a half feet </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; each foot containing four instants, except the sixth of the second line, which contains only one, and is therefore a single short syllable </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; hence there are thirty instants in the first line and twenty-seven in the second) ; [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Old">Old.</a> Germ. <em>&#x00ea;ra</em> ; Mod. Germ. <em>Ehre</em> ; Irish <em>Erin</em>.]</dd>

           <dt>&#x0101;&#x015b;u </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;&#x015b;&#x00fa;</em> mfn. (&#x221a;1. <em>a&#x015b;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#U&#x1e47;">U&#x1e47;.</a> i, 1), fast, quick, going quickly <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>us</em>, or <em>u</em>), m. n. rice ripening quickly in the rainy season <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r">K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>u</em>), n. N. of a S&#x0101;man </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>u</em>), ind. quickly, quick, immediately, directly <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Megh">Megh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> &amp;c.            <dt>&#x0101;&#x015b;rapa&#x1e47;a </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;-&#x015b;rapa&#x1e47;a</em> n. (&#x221a;<em>&#x015b;r&#x0101;</em>), cooking slightly <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Nir">Nir.</a></dd>

   <dt>&#x0101;&#x015b;rama </dt>
   <dd><em>&#x0101;-&#x015b;rama</em> <em>as</em>, <em>am</em> m. n. (&#x221a;<em>&#x015b;ram</em>), a hermitage, the abode of ascetics, the cell of a hermit or of retired saints or sages <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Megh">Megh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a stage in the life of a Br&#x0101;hman (of which there are four corresponding to four different periods or conditions, viz. 1st, Brahmac&#x0101;rin, 'student of the Veda' ; 2nd, G&#x1e5b;iha-stha, 'householder' ; 3rd, V&#x0101;naprastha, 'anchorite' </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; and 4th, Sa&#x1e43;ny&#x0101;sin, 'abandoner of all worldly concerns', or sometimes Bhikshu, 'religious beggar' </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; in some places the law-givers mention only three such periods of religious life, the first being then omitted) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a hut built on festal occasions <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a college, school </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a wood or thicket <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; m. N. of a pupil of P&#x1e5b;ithvii-dhara</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; &#x0101;&#x015b;ramaguru </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;guru</em> m. the head of a religious order, a principal preceptor</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to join <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> &amp;c </dd>

   <dt>&#x226b; &#x0101;&#x015b;raya </dt>
   <dd><em>&#x0101;-&#x015b;raya</em> m. that to which anything is annexed or with which anything is closely connected or on which anything depends or rests <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a recipient, the person or thing in which any quality or article is inherent or retained or received </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; seat, resting-place <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; dwelling, asylum, place of refuge, shelter <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;i&#x015b;">&#x015a;i&#x015b;.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; depending on, having recourse to </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; help, assistance, protection <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; authority, sanction, warrant </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; a plea, excuse <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

   <dd>&#x2022; attaching to, choosing, taking </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; joining, union, attachment </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; dependance, contiguity, vicinity <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RPr&#x0101;t">RPr&#x0101;t.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; relation </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; connection </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; appropriate act or one consistent with the character of the agent </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (in Gr.) the subject, that to which the predicate is annexed </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; (with Buddhists) the five organs of sense with <em>manas</em> or mind (the six together being the recipients of the <em>&#x0101;&#x015b;rita</em> or objects which enter them by way of their <em>&#x0101;lambana</em> or qualities) </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; source, origin </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; ifc. depending on, resting on, endowed or furnished with (e.g. <em>a&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a-gu&#x1e47;&#x00e2;&#x015b;raya</em>, under <em>a&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em>)</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>am</em>), n. (with Buddhists) an object perceived by the senses and <em>manas</em> or mind</dd>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;dugh</em> mfn. milking for a mixture with Soma <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r">&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x0101;&#x015b;ru </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;-&#x221a;&#x015b;ru</em> P. <em>-&#x015b;&#x1e5b;&#x1e47;oti</em> &#x0100;. <em>-&#x015b;&#x1e5b;&#x1e47;ute</em>, to listen to </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to hear </dd>

   <dd><em>&#x0101;s</em> ind. (an interjection implying joy, anger, menace, pain, affliction, recollection) Ah! Oh! &amp;c. <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p159-3"></a>[Page 159, Column 3]</font>
</dd>

           <dt>&#x0101;s 2</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;s</em> cl. 2. &#x0100;. <em>&#x0101;&#x0341;ste</em> (and <em>&#x0101;&#x0341;sate</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> xi, 8, 32, &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Impv. 2. sg. <em>&#x0101;s-sva</em>, <em>&#x0101;sva</em>, and <em>&#x0101;sasva</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 2. pl. <em>&#x0101;dhvam</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; p. <em>&#x0101;s&#x0101;n&#x00e1;</em>, <em>&#x0101;sat</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a>], and <em>&#x0101;s&#x012b;na</em> <em>see below</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x0101;s&#x0101;&#x1e43;-cakre</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 3-1, 87] </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x0101;si&#x1e63;yate</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x0101;si&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x0101;situm</em>) to sit, sit down, rest, lie <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be present </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to exist </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to inhabit, dwell in </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to make one's abode in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to sit quietly, abide, remain, continue <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cease, have an end <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to solemnize, celebrate </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to do anything without interruption </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to continue doing anything </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to continue in any situation </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to last </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (it is used in the sense of 'continuing', with a participle, adj., or subst., e.g. <em>etat s&#x0101;ma g&#x0101;yann &#x0101;ste</em>, 'he continues singing this verse' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with an indeclinable participle in <em>tv&#x0101;</em>, <em>ya</em>, or <em>am</em> e.g. <em>upa-rudhya arim &#x0101;s&#x012b;ta</em>, 'he should continue blockading the foe' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with an adverb, e.g. <em>t&#x016b;&#x1e63;&#x1e47;&#x012b;m &#x0101;ste</em>, 'he continues quiet' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>sukham &#x0101;sva</em>, 'continue well' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with an inst. case, e.g. <em>sukhen&#x00e2;ste</em>, 'he continues well' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with a dat. case, e.g. <em>&#x0101;st&#x0101;&#x1e43; tu&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;aye</em>, 'may it be to your satisfaction'): Caus. <em>&#x0101;sayati</em>, to cause any one to sit down <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Comm">Comm.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a>: Desid. &#x0100;. <em>&#x0101;sisi&#x1e63;ate</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> ; [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Gk">Gk.</a> ?, ?: Lat. <em>&#x00e2;sa</em> changed to <em>&#x00e2;ra</em> ; [159, 3] <em>&#x00e2;-nus</em> for <em>&#x00e2;s-nus</em>.]</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x0101;sa 1</dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; to manifest, utter, speak <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> &amp;c.: Caus. P. &#x0100;. <em>-h&#x0101;rayati</em>, <em>-te</em>, to cause to fetch </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to cause to bring, collect (taxes) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x0101;hl&#x0101;din </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;-hl&#x0101;din</em> mfn. causing joy or delight, Ratn&#x0101;v</dd>

           <dt>&#x0101;hv&#x1e5b; </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; to hurt, injure</dd>

           <dd><em>&#x0101;-hruta</em> mfn. stooped, crooked </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; hurt, wounded</dd>

   <dt>&#x0101;hve </dt>
   <dd><em>&#x0101;-&#x221a;hve</em> P. <em>-hvayati</em> (but also Pot. 1. sg. <em>&#x0101;-huvema</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> vii, 85, 1), &#x0100;. <em>-hvayate</em> (but also 1. sg. <em>&#x0101;&#x0341;-huve</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; aor. 3. pl. <em>&#x00e2;&#x0341;h&#x016b;&#x1e63;ata</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 14, 2, &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; Inf. <em>-huv&#x00e1;dhyai</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> vi, 60, 13, and <em>-hvayitava&#x00ed;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> ii, 5, 3, 18) to call near, invoke invite, summon, cite <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <br>          <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x1e5b;icch">M&#x1e5b;icch.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to provoke, challenge, emulate (in this sense only &#x0100;. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-3, 31) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> &amp;c </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to call to (especially in rites said of the Hot&#x1e5b;i, who addresses the Adhvaryu by the &#x0100;-h&#x0101;va or &#x0100;-hv&#x0101;na </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; below)         <br>          <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r">&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r">K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;khBr">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;khBr.</a> and &#x015a;r </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to proclaim <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r">K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r">&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r.</a>: Caus. <em>-hv&#x0101;yayati</em>, to cause to call near, send for </dd>
   <dd>&#x2022; to cause to summon or challenge or invite <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;">Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.</a>: Desid. <em>-juh&#x016b;&#x1e63;ati</em>, to wish to call near, to be about to call near: Intens. <em>&#x0101;&#x0341;-johaviiti</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> vii, 56, 18, to call near zealously</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; &#x0101;hava 2</dt>
           <dd><em>&#x0101;-hav&#x00e1;</em> m. challenge, provoking </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; war, battle <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhag">Bhag.</a> &amp;c</dd>

   <dt>&#x226b; &#x0101;h&#x0101;va 2</dt>
   <dd><em>&#x0101;-h&#x0101;va</em> m. a particular invocation (<em>&#x015b;o&#x1e43;s&#x0101;vom</em> corrupt from <em>&#x015b;a&#x1e43;s&#x0101;va</em>, 'let us two pray!') by which the Hot&#x1e5b;i addresses the Adhvaryu <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r">&#x0100;&#x015b;v&#x015a;r.</a> (cf. <em>&#x0101;-hv&#x0101;na</em>) </dd>

   <dd>&#x2022; (for 1. <em>&#x0101;-h&#x0101;va</em> <em>&#x0101;-&#x221a;hu</em>.)</dd>

   <dt>&#x226b; &#x0101;huti 2</dt>

   <dd>&#x2022; (for 1. <em>&#x0101;-huti</em> <em>&#x0101;-&#x221a;hu</em>.)</dd>
